meaning: so high as to prevent the purchase or use of; forbidding;

adjective.definition: (of a law or rule) forbidding or restricting something.
adjective.example: prohibitive legislation

adjective.definition: (of a price or charge) excessively high; difficult or impossible to pay.
adjective.example: the costs involved were prohibitive

verb.definition: Increase rapidly in numbers; multiply.
verb.example: the science fiction magazines that proliferated in the 1920s

noun.definition: An inclination or natural tendency to behave in a particular way.
noun.example: a propensity for violence

verb.definition: Win or regain the favor of (a god, spirit, or person) by doing something that pleases them.
verb.example: the pagans thought it was important to propitiate the gods with sacrifices

noun.definition: The state or quality of conforming to conventionally accepted standards of behavior or morals.
noun.example: he always behaved with the utmost propriety

verb.definition: Forbid, especially by law.
verb.example: strikes remained proscribed in the armed forces

adjective.definition: Making or indicative of timely preparation for the future.
adjective.example: she had learned to be provident

adjective.definition: Having great power or influence.
adjective.example: he would become a puissant man

meaning: careful in observing rules fo behavior

adjective.definition: Showing great attention to detail or correct behavior.
adjective.example: he was punctilious in providing every amenity for his guests

adjective.definition: Having a sharply strong taste or smell.
adjective.example: the pungent smell of frying onions

adjective.definition: Showing a lack of courage or determination; timid.

verb.definition: Appear or claim to be or do something, especially falsely; profess.
verb.example: she is not the person she purports to be

noun.definition: The meaning or substance of something, typically a document or speech.
noun.example: I do not understand the purport of your remarks

noun.definition: A soft boggy area of land that gives way underfoot.
noun.example: torrential rain turned the building site into a quagmire

noun.definition: A small, short-tailed Old World game bird resembling a small partridge, typically having brown camouflaged plumage.
A small or medium-sized New World game bird, the male of which has distinctive facial markings.

verb.definition: Feel or show fear or apprehension.
verb.example: she quailed at his heartless words

adjective.definition: Officially recognized as being trained to perform a particular job; certified.
adjective.example: newly qualified nurses

adjective.definition: Not complete or absolute; limited.
adjective.example: I could only judge this CD a qualified success

meaning: sudden feeling of faintness or nausea

noun.definition: An uneasy feeling of doubt, worry, or fear, especially about one's own conduct; a misgiving.
noun.example: military regimes generally have no qualms about controlling the press

noun.definition: A question, especially one addressed to an official or organization.
noun.example: a spokeswoman said queries could not be answered until Monday

verb.definition: Ask a question about something, especially in order to express one's doubts about it or to check its validity or accuracy.
verb.example: many people queried whether any harm had been done

meaning: to argue over insignificant and irrelevant details

noun.definition: A slight objection or criticism about a trivial matter.
noun.example: the only quibble about this book is the price

noun.definition: A play on words; a pun.

verb.definition: Argue or raise objections about a trivial matter.
verb.example: they are always quibbling about the amount they are prepared to pay

adjective.definition: In a state or period of inactivity or dormancy.
adjective.example: strikes were headed by groups of workers who had previously been quiescent

meaning: number of memeber necessary to conduct a meeting

noun.definition: The minimum number of members of an assembly or society that must be present at any of its meetings to make the proceedings of that meeting valid.
A person who tells anecdotes in a skillful and amusing way.
noun.example: a colorful raconteur

meaning: to scold with bitter or abusive language

noun.definition: A bar or series of bars, typically fixed on upright supports, serving as part of a fence or barrier or used to hang things on.
A steel bar or continuous line of bars laid on the ground as one of a pair forming a railroad track.
noun.example: trolley rails

noun.definition: The edge of a surfboard or sailboard.
A horizontal piece in the frame of a paneled door or sash window.
A conductor which is maintained at a fixed potential and to which other parts of a circuit are connected.

verb.definition: Provide or enclose (a space or place) with a rail or rails.
verb.example: the altar is railed off from the nave

verb.definition: (in windsurfing) sail the board on its edge, so that it is at a sharp angle to the surface of the water.
Complain or protest strongly and persistently about.
verb.example: he railed at human fickleness

noun.definition: A secretive bird with drab gray and brown plumage, typically having a long bill and found in dense waterside vegetation.
Clothing.
noun.example: ladies clothed in raiment bedecked with jewels

noun.definition: A consequence of an action or event, especially when complex or unwelcome.
noun.example: any change is bound to have legal ramifications

adjective.definition: (of air, especially that at high altitudes) of lower pressure than usual; thin.
Distant from the lives and concerns of ordinary people.
adjective.example: debates about the nature of knowledge can seem very rarefied

noun.definition: A set of reasons or a logical basis for a course of action or a particular belief.
noun.example: he explained the rationale behind the change

meaning: puzzle in whic pictures or symbols represent words

adjective.definition: Having an obstinately uncooperative attitude toward authority or discipline.
adjective.example: a class of recalcitrant fifteen-year-olds

noun.definition: A person with an obstinately uncooperative attitude.

verb.definition: Say that one no longer holds an opinion or belief, especially one considered heretical.
verb.example: heretics were burned if they would not recant

meaning: person who lives in seclusion and often in solitude

noun.definition: A person who lives a solitary life and tends to avoid other people.
noun.example: she has turned into a virtual recluse

adjective.definition: Favoring a solitary life.
(of a subject or knowledge) little known; abstruse.
adjective.example: the book is full of recondite information

adjective.definition: (of a person) formidable, especially as an opponent.
adjective.example: he was a redoubtable debater

meaning: stubborn; resisting ordinary methods of treatment;

adjective.definition: Stubborn or unmanageable.
adjective.example: his refractory pony

adjective.definition: Resistant to a process or stimulus.
adjective.example: some granules are refractory to secretory stimuli

noun.definition: A substance that is resistant to heat.

adjective.definition: Shining brightly.
adjective.example: refulgent blue eyes

verb.definition: Prove (a statement or theory) to be wrong or false; disprove.
verb.example: these claims have not been convincingly refuted
synonyms: drive a coach and horses through

verb.definition: Entertain or amuse (someone) with talk.
verb.example: he regaled her with a colorful account of that afternoon's meeting

meaning: to consign to an inferior position

verb.definition: Consign or dismiss to an inferior rank or position.
verb.example: they aim to prevent women from being relegated to a secondary role

verb.definition: Make a forcefully reproachful protest.
verb.example: he turned angrily to remonstrate with Tommy

meaning: to go back on one's word

verb.definition: Go back on a promise, undertaking, or contract.
verb.example: the administration had reneged on its election promises

noun.definition: The making of amends for a wrong one has done, by paying money to or otherwise helping those who have been wronged.
noun.example: the courts required a convicted offender to make financial reparation to his victim

noun.definition: The action of repairing something.
noun.example: the old hall was pulled down to avoid the cost of reparation

verb.definition: Feel or express discontent; fret.
verb.example: you mustn't let yourself repine

meaning: repetition; especially of a piece of music;

noun.definition: A repeated passage in music.

verb.definition: Repeat (a piece of music or a performance).
Address (someone) in such a way as to express disapproval or disappointment.
verb.example: “You know that isn't true,” he reproached her

noun.definition: The expression of disapproval or disappointment.
noun.example: he gave her a look of reproach

noun.definition: An unprincipled person (often used humorously or affectionately).
(in Calvinism) a sinner who is not of the elect and is predestined to damnation.

adjective.definition: Unprincipled (often used as a humorous or affectionate reproach)
adjective.example: a long-missed old reprobate drinking comrade

adjective.definition: (in Calvinism) predestined to damnation.

verb.definition: Express or feel disapproval of.
verb.example: his neighbors reprobated his method of proceeding

meaning: to reject as having no authority

verb.definition: Refuse to accept or be associated with.
verb.example: she has repudiated policies associated with previous party leaders
synonyms: have nothing more to do with

verb.definition: Revoke, cancel, or repeal (a law, order, or agreement)
verb.example: the government eventually rescinded the directive

noun.definition: A firm decision to do or not to do something.
noun.example: she kept her resolution not to see Anne any more

noun.definition: The quality of being determined or resolute.
noun.example: he handled the last French actions of the war with resolution

noun.definition: The action of solving a problem, dispute, or contentious matter.
noun.example: the peaceful resolution of all disputes

noun.definition: The process of reducing or separating something into its components.
The smallest interval measurable by a scientific (especially optical) instrument; the resolving power.
The conversion of something abstract into another form.
noun.example: the gradual resolution of an uncertain feeling into a named emotion

verb.definition: Settle or find a solution to (a problem, dispute, or contentious matter)
verb.example: the firm aims to resolve problems within 30 days

verb.definition: Decide firmly on a course of action.
verb.example: she resolved to call Dana as soon as she got home

verb.definition: Separate or cause to be separated into components.
(of something seen at a distance) turn into a different form when seen more clearly.
verb.example: the orange glow resolved itself into four lanterns

noun.definition: Firm determination to do something.
noun.example: she received information that strengthened her resolve

adjective.definition: Not revealing one's thoughts or feelings readily.
adjective.example: she was extremely reticent about her personal affairs
synonyms: wouldn't say boo to a goose

adjective.definition: Feeling or showing deep and solemn respect.
adjective.example: a reverent silence

noun.definition: A quick, clever reply to an insult or criticism.
A quick return thrust following a parry.

verb.definition: Make a quick, clever reply to an insult or criticism.
verb.example: “I'd have made lamb chops had I known you're a vegetarian,” Kris riposted

verb.definition: Make a quick return thrust in fencing.

adjective.definition: (of furniture or architecture) of or characterized by an elaborately ornamental late baroque style of decoration prevalent in 18th-century Continental Europe, with asymmetrical patterns involving motifs and scrollwork.
adjective.example: a rococo carved gilt mirror

noun.definition: The rococo style of art, decoration, or architecture.
noun.example: rococo is alive and living in our hearts

noun.definition: A heading on a document.

verb.definition: Bitterly regret (something one has done or allowed to happen)
verb.example: Ferguson will rue the day he turned down that offer

noun.definition: Repentance; regret.
noun.example: with rue my heart is laden

noun.definition: A perennial evergreen shrub with bitter strong-scented lobed leaves which are used in herbal medicine.
An action intended to deceive someone; a trick.
noun.example: Eleanor tried to think of a ruse to get Paul out of the house

proper noun.definition: An industrial city and the principal port of Bulgaria, on the Danube River; population 156,959 (2008).

noun.definition: An aromatic plant with grayish-green leaves that are used as a culinary herb, native to southern Europe and the Mediterranean.
Either of two bushy North American plants with silvery-gray leaves.
short for sagebrush
A profoundly wise man, especially one who features in ancient history or legend.

adjective.definition: Having, showing, or indicating profound wisdom.
adjective.example: they nodded in agreement with these sage remarks

adjective.definition: Having or conveying undue or inappropriate interest in sexual matters.
adjective.example: salacious stories

adjective.definition: Health-giving; healthy.
adjective.example: salubrious weather

meaning: expecting an improvement; favorable to health;

adjective.definition: (especially with reference to something unwelcome or unpleasant) producing good effects; beneficial.
adjective.example: a salutary reminder of where we came from

noun.definition: A threatened penalty for disobeying a law or rule.
noun.example: a range of sanctions aimed at deterring insider abuse

noun.definition: Official permission or approval for an action.
noun.example: he appealed to the bishop for his sanction

verb.definition: Give official permission or approval for (an action)
verb.example: only two treatments have been sanctioned by the Food and Drug Administration

verb.definition: Impose a sanction or penalty on.

adjective.definition: Grimly mocking or cynical.
adjective.example: Starkey attempted a sardonic smile

adjective.definition: Relating to tailoring, clothes, or style of dress.
adjective.example: sartorial elegance

verb.definition: another term for sate
verb.example: he folded up his newspaper, his curiosity satiated

adjective.definition: Satisfied to the full; satiated.

verb.definition: Cause (something) to become thoroughly soaked with liquid so that no more can be absorbed.
verb.example: the soil is saturated

noun.definition: A saturated fat.

adjective.definition: Saturated with moisture.
(of a person or their manner) slow and gloomy.
adjective.example: a saturnine temperament

meaning: a creature that is half-man; half beast; with the horns and legs of a goat

noun.definition: One of a class of lustful, drunken woodland gods. In Greek art they were represented as a man with a horse's ears and tail, but in Roman representations as a man with a goat's ears, tail, legs, and horns.
A satyrid butterfly with chiefly dark brown wings.

meaning: to enjoy; have a distinctive flavor or smell;

verb.definition: Taste (good food or drink) and enjoy it completely.
verb.example: gourmets will want to savor our game specialties

verb.definition: Have a suggestion or trace of (something, especially something bad)
verb.example: their genuflections savored of superstition and popery

noun.definition: A characteristic taste, flavor, or smell, especially a pleasant one.
noun.example: the subtle savor of wood smoke

meaning: relating to or in the form of an outline or diagram

adjective.definition: (of a diagram or other representation) symbolic and simplified.

noun.definition: (in technical contexts) a schematic diagram, in particular of an electric or electronic circuit.

meaning: produce and release substance into organism

verb.definition: (of a cell, gland, or organ) produce and discharge (a substance)
verb.example: insulin is secreted in response to rising levels of glucose in the blood

verb.definition: Conceal; hide.
verb.example: the assets had been secreted in Swiss bank accounts

noun.definition: Conduct or speech inciting people to rebel against the authority of a state or monarch.

adjective.definition: (of a person or action) showing dedication and diligence.
adjective.example: he watched himself with the most sedulous care

adjective.definition: Relating to earthquakes or other vibrations of the earth and its crust.

meaning: relating to the senses; gratifying the physical (sexual) senses;

adjective.definition: Relating to or involving gratification of the senses and physical, especially sexual, pleasure.
adjective.example: the production of the ballet is sensual and passionate

adjective.definition: Relating to or affecting the senses rather than the intellect.
adjective.example: the work showed a deliberate disregard of the more sensuous and immediately appealing aspects of painting

adjective.definition: Attractive or gratifying physically, especially sexually.
adjective.example: her voice was rather deep but very sensuous

adjective.definition: Able to perceive or feel things.
adjective.example: she had been instructed from birth in the equality of all sentient life forms

adjective.definition: Having or showing an excessive willingness to serve or please others.
adjective.example: he bowed his head in a servile manner

adjective.definition: Of or characteristic of a slave or slaves.

meaning: navigation tool that determines latitude and longitude

noun.definition: An instrument with a graduated arc of 60° and a sighting mechanism, used for measuring the angular distances between objects and especially for taking altitudes in navigation.

meaning: a piece of broken glass or pottery

noun.definition: A piece of broken ceramic, metal, glass, or rock, typically having sharp edges.
noun.example: shards of glass flew in all directions

adjective.definition: Of or with respect to the distant stars (i.e. the constellations or fixed stars, not the sun or planets).
Relating to, resembling, or affecting apes or monkeys.
adjective.example: simian immunodeficiency virus

noun.definition: An ape or monkey.

meaning: "comparison of one thing with another using ""like"" or ""as"""

noun.definition: A figure of speech involving the comparison of one thing with another thing of a different kind, used to make a description more emphatic or vivid (e.g., as brave as a lion, crazy like a fox).

meaning: well-paying job that requieres little or no work

noun.definition: A position requiring little or no work but giving the holder status or financial benefit.
noun.example: political sinecures for the supporters of ministers

adjective.definition: (of a word or form) denoting or referring to just one person or thing.
Exceptionally good or great; remarkable.
adjective.example: the singular beauty of the desert

adjective.definition: (of a square matrix) having a zero determinant.
Denoting a point that is a singularity.

noun.definition: The singular form of a word.
noun.example: the first person singular

adjective.definition: Having many curves and turns.
adjective.example: the river follows a sinuous trail through the forest

noun.definition: A person inclined to question or doubt accepted opinions.
An ancient or modern philosopher who denies the possibility of knowledge, or even rational belief, in some sphere.

adjective.definition: another term for skeptical

noun.definition: The state of being sober.
noun.example: the price of beer compelled me to maintain a certain level of sobriety

adjective.definition: Saturated with liquid, especially water; soaked through.
adjective.example: his clothes were sodden

verb.definition: Saturate (something) with water.

adjective.definition: Characterized by or showing interest or concern.
adjective.example: she was always solicitous about the welfare of her students

meaning: literary or dramatic speech by one character; not adressed to others;

noun.definition: An act of speaking one's thoughts aloud when by oneself or regardless of any hearers, especially by a character in a play.
noun.example: Edmund ends the scene as he had begun it, with a soliloquy

adjective.definition: Having assets in excess of liabilities; able to pay one's debts.
adjective.example: interest rate rises have very severe effects on normally solvent companies

adjective.definition: Able to dissolve other substances.
adjective.example: osmotic, chemical, or solvent action

noun.definition: The liquid in which a solute is dissolved to form a solution.

meaning: relating to or affecting the body; corporeal;

adjective.definition: Relating to the body, especially as distinct from the mind.
adjective.example: patients completed a questionnaire about their somatic and psychological symptoms

adjective.definition: Tending to induce drowsiness or sleep.
adjective.example: the motion of the train had a somewhat soporific effect

noun.definition: A drug or other agent that induces sleep.

adjective.definition: Involving ignoble actions and motives; arousing moral distaste and contempt.
adjective.example: the story paints a sordid picture of bribes and scams

meaning: seeming to be logical and sound; but not really so;

adjective.definition: Superficially plausible, but actually wrong.
adjective.example: a specious argument

meaning: band of color; broad range of related ideas or objects;

noun.definition: A band of colors, as seen in a rainbow, produced by separation of the components of light by their different degrees of refraction according to wavelength.
Used to classify something, or suggest that it can be classified, in terms of its position on a scale between two extreme or opposite points.
noun.example: the left or the right of the political spectrum

noun.definition: A person who spends money in an extravagant, irresponsible way.
noun.example: Putt was a spendthrift and a heavy gambler

adjective.definition: Occurring at irregular intervals or only in a few places; scattered or isolated.
adjective.example: sporadic fighting broke out

noun.definition: The state of being extremely dirty and unpleasant, especially as a result of poverty or neglect.
noun.example: they lived in squalor and disease

adverb & adjective.definition: With each sound or note sharply detached or separated from the others.

noun.definition: A piece or passage marked to be performed staccato.

meaning: to stop or check the flow of

verb.definition: Stop or restrict (a flow of blood) from a wound.
verb.example: colleagues may have saved her life by stanching the flow

adjective.definition: archaic spelling of staunch
